q: Most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia in immunocompetent adults?
explanation: Streptococcus pneumoniae remains the leading cause of CAP in otherwise healthy adults.

q: Best initial management step in diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)?
explanation: Volume resuscitation with isotonic saline is the first step; insulin and potassium are added after labs and partial fluid replacement.

q: Earliest ECG change in hyperkalemia is typically:
explanation: Tall, peaked T waves usually appear first as serum potassium rises.

q: Which therapy improves survival in HFrEF (reduced EF)?
explanation: ACE inhibitors (or ARNI), evidence-based beta-blockers, and MRAs improve survival; loop diuretics and digoxin mainly relieve symptoms.

q: Best reperfusion strategy for a STEMI patient at a PCI-capable center within guideline time windows:
explanation: Primary percutaneous coronary intervention within door-to-balloon time offers superior outcomes when rapidly available.

q: Most specific serologic test for rheumatoid arthritis:
explanation: Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies have high specificity for RA.

q: Nephrotic syndrome is defined by daily proteinuria greater than:
explanation: Nephrotic-range proteinuria is >3.5 g/day, typically with hypoalbuminemia and edema.

q: First-line bronchodilator in an acute severe asthma exacerbation:
explanation: Short-acting beta-2 agonists are first-line; ipratropium and systemic steroids are adjuncts.

q: In suspected infective endocarditis, key step before starting empiric antibiotics:
options: Obtain three sets of blood cultures
explanation: Multiple blood cultures drawn before antibiotics maximize microbiologic yield.

q: Most appropriate initial screening test for hypothyroidism:
explanation: TSH is the best initial test; free T4 helps confirm and grade severity.
